concept.title: Adjusting the Margins and Line Spacing
concept.shortdesc: Learn how to set the left and right margins and choose single or double line spacing on a typewriter.

conbody.p: Margins and line spacing control where your text begins and ends on a page and how much space appears between each line. Setting them correctly helps your document look neat and organized.

To set the left margin, move the margin stop on the left side of the carriage to the position where you want each line to start. To set the right margin, move the right margin stop to where you want the line to end. These stops prevent the carriage from moving beyond the set points while typing.

Most typewriters have a line spacing lever or selector near the carriage. You can adjust it to choose between single spacing (1) or double spacing (2). Single spacing is useful for drafts or notes, while double spacing is ideal for clean copies or documents that need editing.
After setting margins and spacing, test them by typing a few lines on scrap paper. Adjust as needed until your text fits neatly on the page and looks evenly spaced.
